official-title.#text:
To amend the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 and title 5, United States Code, to
			 require plans to establish policies addressing firm-specific risks in
			 asset management services, greater diversification in investment
			 strategies, and the inclusion of diverse asset managers and minority
			 brokerage firms, and for other purposes.

committee-name.#tail: , and in addition to the Committee on
committee-name.#text: Committee on Oversight and Government Reform

committee-name.#tail:
, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such
			 provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: American Pension Investments Modernization Act of 2014
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: American Pension Investments Modernization Act of 2014

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

header.#text: Consideration of firm-specific risks and inclusion of diverse asset managers in ERISA plans

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Section 404(a) of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974/s:404/ss:a

text.#text: in paragraph (1)—
in subparagraph (C), by striking
by designating subparagraph (D) as subparagraph (E); and
by inserting after subparagraph (C) the following:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, or business enterprise or enterprises
			 for brokerage and investment banking services, by establishing policies
			 under which the fiduciary will consider—
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: International Women’s Freedom Act of 2013/s:402/ss:c/p:3

text.#text:
in any case in which the fiduciary appoints an investment manager or managers to manage any assets
			 of a plan under

the concentration level of the plan’s exposure to firm-specific risks, including operational,
			 compliance, and fraud risks;

the inclusion, to the greatest extent feasible, of minority business enterprises for brokerage and
			 investment banking services; and

the utilization of diverse asset managers, taking into consideration the investment opportunities
			 they offer in sectors, strategies, geographies, and demographics not
			 meaningfully available to the plans.
by inserting at the end the following:
For purposes of this subsection, the term

not less than 51 percent of which is owned by one or more individuals described in subparagraph (C)
			 or, in the case of any publicly owned business, not less than 51 percent
			 of the stock of which is owned by such individuals; or

not less than 35 percent of which is owned by one or more individuals described in subparagraph (C)
			 or, in the case of any publicly owned business, not less than 35 percent
			 of the stock of which is owned by such individuals; and

the management and daily business operations of which are controlled by one or more individuals
			 described in subparagraph (C).

quote.#tail:
means a minority business enterprise that manages an investment portfolio of at least $100,000,000
			 and not more than $25,000,000,000.

text.#text: For purposes of this subsection, the term
An individual described in this subparagraph is—

an African-American, Hispanic-American, Asian Pacific American, Subcontinent Asian American, or
			 Native American;
a woman; or
a veteran (as defined in

shall
			 issue guidance relating to the requirement imposed by

(as amended by subsection (a)). In issuing guidance under this
			 subsection, the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974/s:404/ss:a/p:1/sp:D

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall consider successful practices
			 from State, local, and private-sector retirement systems’ utilization of
			 diverse and emerging asset managers and of minority business enterprises
			 for brokerage and investment banking services, including established
			 efforts, programs, plans, and goals designed to increase their
			 participation in financial services, and providing pension plans with
			 greater access to investment opportunities that may otherwise be
			 overlooked.

text.#text: Not later than 1 year after the date of the enactment of this Act, the

header.#text: Issuance of guidance by Secretary of Labor

Consideration of firm-specific risks and inclusion of diverse asset managers in the Thrift Savings
			 Plan

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , is amended by adding at the end the following:

text.#text:
In establishing policies under subsection (f)(1)(A), the Board shall take into account the guidance
			 issued by the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 404(a)(1)(D) of the
			 Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974/s:404/ss:a/p:1/sp:D

quote.#text: and consistent with the policies developed under

header.#text: Active management option under the Thrift Savings Plan

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, is amended by inserting at the end the
			 following:
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: usc-chapter/5/84/III

text.#text:
The Board shall provide employees and Members and former employees or Members the option to
			 participate in actively managed funds within such employee or Member’s
			 Thrift Savings Fund account. Such option or options shall allow not more
			 than 20 percent of an employee or Member’s (or former employee or
			 Member’s) funds to be actively managed.

Notwithstanding the requirement of subsection (a), the Board may not subject more than 20 percent
			 of the total assets under management of the Thrift Savings Fund to active
			 management.

The Board shall promulgate guidelines regarding the active management of funds under this section.
			 In promulgating such guidelines, the Board shall consider modern and
			 successful practices from State, local, and private-sector retirement
			 systems’ utilization of active management strategies in order to—

reduce market downside risks to the best extent possible, including dramatic swings in major market
			 indexes;

take advantage of research and investment opportunities offered by small-, minority-, women- and
			 veteran-owned firms that specialize in less traditional asset classes, or
			 less efficient market segments with high-growth potentials, including
			 investments in sectors, strategies, geographies and demographics that are
			 not meaningfully available to large passively invested funds; and

take advantage of more effective portfolio designs that diversify across active and passive
			 investment strategies and managers.
The table of sections for such subchapter is amended by adding after the item relating to

the fees charged by each firm used for brokerage and investment banking services.
